description: William Marcrum, Perry County health officer, said one of the nine new cases is an inmate at Branchville Correctional Facility. None are connected to Golden LivingCenters in Tell City and Dr. Marcrum added that those three cases have since tested negative and are believed to be false positives, but they're treated as positive just to be safe.
text:
PERRY COUNTY  Nine new COVID-19 cases were confirmed in Perry County between
Wednesday and Friday, bringing the total number of cases to 49.

According to information from the Perry County Health Department, all five of
the new cases are in isolation. Dr. William Marcrum, Perry County health
officer, said one of the nine new cases is an inmate at Branchville
Correctional Facility (where four staff and eight inmates have previously
tested positive).

None are connected to Golden LivingCenters in Tell City and Dr. Marcrum added
that those three cases have since tested negative and are believed to be false
positives, but they're treated as positive just to be safe.

"The state says if you have a positive test, you are positive," Dr. Marcrum
said.

Public Health Nurse Tara Lucas said the health department is urging local
residents to continue to practice good hand hygiene, social distancing and use
of face masks.

"Just because we're opening up some doesn't mean that COVID is gone," Lucas
said. "We still need to be aware and cautious."

Lucas added that a major cause of concern is the possibility that people who
should have been self-isolating because of their own exposure might have
exposed the people who are newly diagnosed. The Indiana State Department of
Health surveyed 3,600 Hoosiers and found 45% of them who tested positive for
active virus or its antibodies had no symptoms at all. The Centers for Disease
Control and Prevention  among others  have confirmed that people can pass
the novel coronavirus even without symptoms.

"If you are ill, please stay home. Do not go to work, to Wal-Mart or anywhere
public," Lucas said. "If you are contacted by us because you've been confirmed
as a close contact of someone who tested positive, you have to stay home."

Lucas added that the department needs the public to help them prevent the
virus from spreading.

If you've been deemed as a close contact to a known positive and have been put
on isolation, please follow those guidelines. Period," Lucas said. "We need
people to work with us. If we've called you and said you're a close contact,
please respect that for the common good of the entire county."

title: Nine new COVID-19 cases in three days
html:
PERRY COUNTY – Nine new COVID-19 cases were confirmed in Perry County between Wednesday and Friday, bringing the total number of cases to 49.

According to information from the Perry County Health Department, all five of the new cases are in isolation. Dr. William Marcrum, Perry County health officer, said one of the nine new cases is an inmate at Branchville Correctional Facility (where four staff and eight inmates have previously tested positive).

None are connected to Golden LivingCenters in Tell City and Dr. Marcrum added that those three cases have since tested negative and are believed to be false positives, but they're treated as positive just to be safe.

"The state says if you have a positive test, you are positive," Dr. Marcrum said.

Public Health Nurse Tara Lucas said the health department is urging local residents to continue to practice good hand hygiene, social distancing and use of face masks.

"Just because we're opening up some doesn't mean that COVID is gone," Lucas said. "We still need to be aware and cautious."

Lucas added that a major cause of concern is the possibility that people who should have been self-isolating because of their own exposure might have exposed the people who are newly diagnosed. The Indiana State Department of Health surveyed 3,600 Hoosiers and found 45% of them who tested positive for active virus or its antibodies had no symptoms at all. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention – among others – have confirmed that people can pass the novel coronavirus even without symptoms.

"If you are ill, please stay home. Do not go to work, to Wal-Mart or anywhere public," Lucas said. "If you are contacted by us because you've been confirmed as a close contact of someone who tested positive, you have to stay home."

Lucas added that the department needs the public to help them prevent the virus from spreading.

If you've been deemed as a close contact to a known positive and have been put on isolation, please follow those guidelines. Period," Lucas said. "We need people to work with us. If we've called you and said you're a close contact, please respect that for the common good of the entire county."
